What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
More in-depth knowledge of Spanish grammar
Speaking practice with native Spanish speakers
improved my skills in speaking spanish aloud as well as increased my vocabulary

I grew much more comfortable conversing in Spanish with native speakers and learned a good deal about grammatical topics in which I had never previously been formally instructed (for example, sequence of tenses, adjective placement, less common uses of the subjunctive, etc).
I developed my spoken and written Spanish and learned many new grammatical structures and methods of expressing myself.
Improved my fluency when speaking and writing in Spanish, to the point where I can have a conversation with a native Spanish speaker.
Strengthened my spanish grammar skills. By the end I was much more confident in spoken/written spanish.

I learned a lot about Spanish grammar. The content of the class is basically all the small errors that professors normally overlook, but now you're tested on it. You also learn about Spanish-speaking countries through watching movies.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The biggest strength of the class is the opportunity to have conversations with native speakers. It's a great opportunity to improve fluency and learn about different cultures.
strengths--engagement in seminar and ability to do group and individual work

The opportunities to talk to native speakers through LinguaMeeting and the conversation partner program as well as the small class size were definitely strengths in expanding opportunities to practice speaking in Spanish. Professor Seymour was also kind and enthusiastic, and the course's specific focus on grammar allowed us to delve into details that are often overlooked in Spanish curricula. Another strength was the way that the final grade did not depend too strongly on any one assignment, which helped minimize stress and, in my opinion, is a more fair means of grading. The only potential weakness I can think of is that the homework felt a bit like busywork sometimes, but this probably just a necessity of a grammar-based course.

The different grammatical elements we covered in the course definitely expanded beyond what I had dealt with in AP Spanish in high school, and I came away feeling much more well-equipped to express complex thoughts. The built-in conversational aspects of the class like LinguaMeeting and compaeros de conversacin also added a lot to my skills and confidence.
The main weaknesses of the course were that it was online, and so that made it a bit harder to engage sometimes. However, Prof. Seymour definitely made the online format work.

strengths : Professor was very engaging. Even through an online format, we started off every class by asking each of us how our personal lives were going and what we were up to. Weaknesses : A lot of different tasks. Homework was very consistent between accuracy work, quizzes, completion work, conversations, and recordings.

Strengths: lots of ways to engage with the material
Weaknesses: Sometimes we didn't get through all the material; lots of homework

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: the live seminars were a great way to feel as though i was in a class in person
The format of working in breakout rooms during the class on collaborative google documents worked in increasing engagement, and the virtual native conversations were also beneficial.

The LinguaMeeting coach sessions and the Zoom calls with Ecuadorian university students were a wonderful way of providing opportunities to talk with native speakers despite the pandemic. Furthermore, student participation was a central component of this class, with breakout rooms each session and group participation to help keep us engaged. This may just have been my personal feeling, but, due to the fact that all of our interactions with one another were in a second language, I felt an extra dimension of disconnection from the class community that we would have formed during a normal year, but I'm not sure that there is any clear way to improve upon this.
The partner conversations worked well and were very engaging, but because of issues with my online connection, I sometimes lost parts of the conversation.
I think this was a good mix- it's difficult to teach spanish in a virtual format but this class was exceptional at that.

The breakout rooms were good, but there's no good way to replace the side conversations that happen in Spanish class. Otherwise, the class was conducted the same way that it would've been done in person.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! If you are passionate about the language, grammar is a must. I learned so much and feel much more confident about the things I always swept under the rug.

Yes--if you want to do a focused study of Spanish grammar as well as practice speaking, reading, and writing. I enjoyed the course, especially the Linguameeting and conversation partners components, which gave us the opportunity to talk with native speakers. The workload is consistent but not heavy, and you also get to read short stories and watch movies.
yes! this class made me feel much sharper when it came to understanding spoken spanish

Yes, this is a great class for anyone looking to improve their Spanish skills (especially conversation), particularly if they are interested in Spanish grammar specifically. The workload is reasonable, and the balance between breadth of topics and depth of discussion of each topic was perfect, in my opinion. The opportunities to converse with native speakers (as well as my classmates) helped me feel significantly more comfortable speaking, and I feel like I have a much firmer grasp of many aspects of Spanish grammar than I did before the course. Prof. Seymour is kind, provides ample feedback, and sets a joyful tone for the class. Overall, a great course!
Yes, I would recommend this  course to another student because it is a great balance between teaching new, advanced structures and free, conversational speech to improve fluency.
If you want to improve your Spanish quickly, take this course.

I would recommend this class to another-- It was quite difficult at times, but if you are interested in improving your spanish/confidence in speaking spanish, it is a wonderful class to do so. If you are looking to simply check off your language requirement, I may hesitate given this was a large class to be taking work wise, where every other night I would have to set aside most of the night to be working through the homework. Still doable.

If you love learning Spanish, then yes. I think the class would've been difficult if I didn't already love the language. I wouldn't recommend this class if you are just trying to fulfill a requirement.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
lingua meetings
Native-speaking conversations virtually
In addition to the synchronous seminar, we each had six individual sessions with Spanish coaches through LinguaMeeting and four calls with partner students from Ecuador.
n/a
No other modes of learning
